title: Is the increased strength and stiffness of Mlle L... during hypnosis real or feigned?
first_phrase: This text discusses the possibility of Mlle L... genuinely exhibiting tetanic rigidity and increased strength during somnambulism, rather than merely simulating it. The author refutes claims of superhuman influence and potential imitation, arguing that Mlle L... has naturally weak muscle strength. The text cites personal observations and the findings of a 1825 Parisian Academy committee analyzing magnetic phenomena. To summarize, the author challenges misconceptions about somnambulism and argues for the legitimacy of Mlle L...'s experiences.
content: Un peu grasse, mais lymphatique et de complexion faible, elle est privée de force musculaire. Donato, pendant que Mlle L., après avoir rangé ses effets dans sa malle, s’efforçait de la fermer. Remarquant de loin les grands efforts qu’elle faisait inutilement, je crus que la chose offrait une réelle difficulté : j’offris donc mes services, et je vis qu’une pression insignifiante do ma part suffisait à fermer la malle. J’ai fait depuis moi-même des expériences sur des personnes qui m’étaient bien connues, et je me suis convaincu qu’un grand surcroît de forces à l’état somnambulique est tout à fait admissible (1). last_phrase: In conclusion, the experiences shared in this text show that the somnambulistic state can provide a great increase in strength, as proven by the ease of closing a heavy trunk by someone who struggles under normal circumstances. The difference between lunacy and ecstasy is also explored, with a focus on the latter's susceptibility to the influence of music and subsequent loss of control when the music stops. Understanding the power of the somnambulistic state and its limits can provide useful insights for those seeking to tap into their potential.
